Charon

Charon are the stewards of souls in Marlien, and part of a larger order of Soul Stewards which preside over all of Creation. They may be divided into a number of castes, some of which are incarnations of Divine Atman bound to Marlien, while others are mortal compositions of atman and anicca. They all reside together in the The Halls of the Charon.

Castes of Charon

Immortals

The immortals are the original Soul Stewards from Great Beyond Marlien who were tethered to it, and now serve as the leaders of all charon. Though they are not forced to assume a physical form within this world, that which they are able to assume was dictated by the Dead Gods. They are unwilling prisoners of this creation, locked within it with the souls they seek to protect, until the end of time.

Yamaraj

Mortals

The mortal races of the charon were created by the immortals to bolster their number, serving as their agents and footsoldiers accross Marlien. Most were created by imbuing creatures taken from the Planes with something of the immortals' nature. This process forever alters the mortal soul, and so is considered a desparate measure; the souls of mortal charon are only ever reincarnated in other charon, and it is rare that more are ever created. Though the immortals are capable of manifesting new physical bodies of anicca and mana, most mortal charon are also capable of biological reproduction - some even retain the sexual compatability of the progenitor species.

Memitim

Nosoi

Charon in Other Cultures

Haleysi, Agyanism

Some images and textual references to the charon were passed down through the Warelin people to the Haleysi and other Agyanist folk around the The North Sea of Paraesi, who name them Extinguishers for their role in the destruction of the Goxon and Teigric peoples.

Arthale, Solenism

Some images and textual references to the charon were passed down through the Warelin people to the western folk of the Arthalean Empire and their inheritors. Here they are seen as agents of the beast, Erasors, and enemies of Solen for their role in the destruction of the Goxon and Teigric peoples, along with their vast stores of knowledge and technologies.

Saxi, Eosemir
